Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Mr. Szpilman.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: I came specially to meet you today. I love your playing, but what a day to choose.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: My name's Dorota, I'm Jurek's sister. oh! You're bleeding.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: It's nothing.

Speaker: jurek
Dialogue: C'mon, Dorota, you can write him a fan letter later, this isn't the best time, c'mon.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Jurek, why have you been hiding her?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: What you think, should I take Uncle Szymon's photograph?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Take it, don't take it, take what you like. Can't you see I'm worried sick?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: He'll come home, he'll be all right.

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: Mama, Wladek's home.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Thank God - Wladek! You're wounded.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: It's a little cut, nothing.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I've been worried sick.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: I told her not to worry. You had your papers on you. If you'd been hit by a bomb, they'd have known where to take you.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Henryk, don't say things like that, God forbid, God forbid.

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: Papa, Wladek's home.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: What did I tell you?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: What's it look like we're doing?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: They bombed us, we're off the air.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Warsaw's not the only radio station.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Pack, darling, get your things, pack.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Where are we going?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Out of Warsaw.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Out of Warsaw. Where?

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: You haven't heard?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Heard what?

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: Haven't you seen the paper? Where's the paper?

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: I used it for packing.

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: She used it for packing.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: The government's moved to Lublin.

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: All able-bodied men must leave the city, go across the river and set up a new line of defence, that's what it said.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: There's hardly anybody left in this building, only women, the men have gone.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: And what do you think you'll do while you're setting up a new line of defence? Wander round lugging your suitcases?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Pack, Wladek, there's no time.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I'm not going anywhere.

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: Good! I'm not going anywhere either!

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Don't be ridiculous, we've got to keep together.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: No, no, no, I'm staying put. If I'm going to die, I prefer to die at home.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: God forbid!

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Sssh!

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Ssh! I've got something, listen...

Speaker: radio announcer
Dialogue: ... an important announcement. News has just been received through the BBC that Great Britain, having had no reply...  ... next few hours... awaiting latest news...

Speaker: radio announcer
Dialogue: ... but France is expected to make a similar announcement...  ... Poland is no longer alone.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Mama, that was a great dinner.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: It certainly was.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: When there's something to celebrate, you've got to make an effort.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Here's to Great Britain and France.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: I told you. Didn't I tell you? All will be well.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Five thousand and three.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Is that all?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Yes, five thousand and three zlotys, that's all we've got left.

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: It's three thousand and three zlotys too much,  'Re: Further restrictions regarding liquid assets: Jews will be allowed to keep a maximum of two thousand zlotys in their homes.'

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: What are we supposed to do with the rest?

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: Deposit it in a bank. Blocked account.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Banks? Who'd be stupid enough to deposit money in a German bank?

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: We could hide the money here in the window frame.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: No, no, no. I'll tell you what we'll do. We'll use tried and tested methods. You know what we did in the last war? We made a hole in the table leg and we hid the money in there.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: And suppose they take the table away?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: What d'you mean, take the table away?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: The Germans go into Jewish homes and they just take what they want, furniture, valuables, anything.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Do they?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Idiot! What would they want with a table?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: What on earth are you doing?

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: There's a good place under the cupboard.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: No, no. Listen, I've been thinking --

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: That makes a change.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: You know what we do? We use psychology.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: We use what?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: We leave the money and the watch on the table. And we cover it like this.  In full view. The Germans will search high and low, I promise you, they'll never notice it.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Of course they'll notice it. But look--  This is a good place for something.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: A good place for what?  He's insane!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Just shut up.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: My violin?

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: Quiet! Quiet! Order, please, order!

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: She's a lawyer, she likes order.

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: Listen, just listen. Let's come to an agreement. We jam the money in the window frame. The watch we hide under the cupboard. And the chain we put in the violin.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Will I still be able to play?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Let's find out.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Jurek? Wladek Szpilman.

Speaker: jurek
Dialogue: Wladek! How are you?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Fine, we're fine, thank you, and you?

Speaker: jurek
Dialogue: Fine, we're fine in the circumstances. But I can guess what you've called about. There's nothing we can do; they won't reopen the station--

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Yes, I know, but Jurek, Jurek...

Speaker: jurek
Dialogue: ...not even music, nothing, no radios for the Poles. But I'm sure you'll find work, Wladek, a pianist like you.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Maybe, maybe not, but, Jurek, don't be offended, I didn't call to discuss my future career.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: I nagged Jurek for weeks and weeks. And at last he gave in and said, 'All right, come with me tomorrow,' and so I came and they bombed the station.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: You know something? Meeting you like that was absolutely wonderful.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Yes!  It was...it was unforgettable.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: I've always loved your playing, Mr. Szpilman.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Wladek, please.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: No one plays Chopin like you.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I could accompany you, me on the piano, you on the cello.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Oh, Mr Szpilman, you're quite... quite wonderful.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Wladek, please.

Dialogue: I won't wear it.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Let me see this.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Doesn't it say we have to provide these armbands ourselves? Where will we get them?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: We're not going to get them. We're not going to wear them!

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: You!

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Why didn't you bow?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: I'm sorry I...

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: You are forbidden to walk on the pavement. Walk in the gutter!

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: Have you seen this?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What, I'm working, what?

Speaker: szpilman's voice
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: halina's voice
Dialogue: That's where they're going to put us.

Speaker: szpilman's voice
Dialogue: What d'you mean, put us?

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: 'By order of the Governor of the Warsaw District, Dr. Fischer, concerning the establishment of the Jewish District in Warsaw. And look here: 'Jews living outside of the prescribed area will have to move to the Jewish district by 31st of

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: But...they won't get all of us... we'll...it's too small...there's four hundred thousand of us in Warsaw!

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: No. Three hundred and sixty thousand, so it'll be easy.

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: Mama, what is it?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Twenty zlotys. That's all we've got left. What can I buy with twenty zlotys?  I'm sick of cooking potatoes, potatoes, potatoes.

Speaker: mr lipa
Dialogue: That's the price. That's what I'm offering. And my advice is to accept. You won't get more from anyone else.

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: But...but it's a Steinway, Mr Lipa...

Speaker: mr lipa
Dialogue: Two thousand. My advice is to take it. What you going to do when you're hungry? Eat the piano?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Get out! You're a thieving bastard, we don't want your money, get out! We'd rather give it away! Get out!

Speaker: mr lipa
Dialogue: Hey! Hey! What's the matter with you? Haven't you eaten today, what you suffering from? Hey!

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: Henryk, stop it, leave him alone.

Speaker: mr lipa
Dialogue: You people are crazy! I'm doing you a favour, two thousand, and I'm paying for the removal, I'm not even charging for the removal.

Speaker: mr lipa
Dialogue: You haven't eaten today, you're crazy...

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Take it.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Dorota!

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: I didn't want to come, I didn't want to see all this, but I couldn't stop myself.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: How are you doing?

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Fine, no, not really, they arrested my cousin, but Jurek says they'll let him out.  This is disgraceful.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Don't worry, it won't last long.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: That's what I said, it's so - it's too absurd!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I'll see you...soon.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: To tell you the truth, I thought it would be worse.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: How will we sleep?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I'll sleep with the girls in the kitchen. You, Henrykc and Papa in here.

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: Look! Come and look!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: You sell anything?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Just one. Dostoevsky. The Idiot. Three zlotys.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: That's better than yesterday.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Three lousy zlotys. And there are people here making millions.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: You don't know, believe me. They bribe the guards. The guards turn a blind eye. They're bringing in cartloads, food, tobacco, liquor, French cosmetics, and the poor are dying all around them and they don't give a damn.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I'm afraid not.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Sometimes I wish I could go mad.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Don't worry about it, they're about to build a bridge, haven't you heard?

Speaker: soldiers
Dialogue: Faster! Go on, faster! Dance!

Speaker: soldiers
Dialogue: Dance! Dance!

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Good, they're here. Yitzchak Heller's been waiting for you, Henryk.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: What's this about?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Sit down, have tea, I'll start lunch when the girls get back.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: So, what are you doing here?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: He brought cakes.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: His father's back in the jewellery business and doing well, isn't that so, Yitzchak? Amazing. Jewellery.

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: We're recruiting.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Who's recruiting?

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: Don't be clever with me, Henryk. I've come here as a friend. They're bringing Jews in from all over the country. Soon there'll be half a million people in the ghetto. We need more Jewish police...

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Oh? More Jewish police? You mean you want me to wear a cap like yours, beat up Jews with my truncheon and catch the Gestapo spirit. I see!

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: Someone's got to do it, Henryk.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: But why me? I thought you only recruited boys with rich fathers. Look at my father, look at us, I mean...

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: Yes, I'm looking at you and that's why I'm here. Your whole family can have a better life. You want to go on struggling for survival, selling books on the street?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Yes, please.

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: I'm doing you people a favour. And what about you, Wladek? You're a great pianist. And we've got an excellent police jazz band. They'd welcome you with open arms. Join us. You've got no work...

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Thank you. But I've got work.

Speaker: benek
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Mr Wladek, he wants you to stop.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Who wants me to stop?

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: I always say look on the bright side. You're in the small ghetto, intellectuals, professional people, you're better off than us. Here, in the large ghetto, it's a cesspool. But you, you're living in Monte Carlo. You could say you're privileged and that, of course, goes against my principles. Nevertheless...

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: Ah, here. Today's news from the other side.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: You're amazing, Jehuda.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: No, I'm a socialist. I have brothers everywhere. They bring me news and food. We care about our fellow human beings. Workers of the world unite.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: So, what's the news?

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: The Germans are advancing on Kharkhov.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I don't know why I come here every evening, it's always such bad news.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: Bad news, you crazy? You have no world view, Wladek, that's your trouble. The news couldn't be better. The moment Hitler invaded Russia, I knew we'd be all right. Remember Napoleon. Same business. The Germans will freeze to death, please God.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Jehuda, give me something to do.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: You're an artist, Wladek, you keep people's spirits up. You do enough.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: But I want to help, I want to.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: You're too well known, Wladek. And you know what? You musicians don't make good conspirators. You're too...too musical.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: There are notices going up. The city's to be cleansed of undesirables.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: There are always notices going up.

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: Hello, Symche, Dolek, Mrs Zyskind, Jehuda. Working hard?

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: Majorek, this is the greatest pianist in Poland, maybe in the whole world. Wladyslaw Szpilman. Meet Majorek.

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: I know your name. I've never heard you play.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: Majorek used to be in the army. Brilliant man. He's got a mind like a searchlight. The only thing I've got against him is he's not a socialist.  You see these, Wladek?  You know how many copies we print of our newspaper?

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: Five hundred. You know how many people on average read one copy? Twenty.  That makes ten thousand readers. These will start the uprising. Majorek hides them in his underpants. And leaves them in toilets.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Toilets?

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: As many toilets as I can find. Germans never go into Jewish toilets. They're too clean for them.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: And, please, tonight, for once, I don't want anything bad talked about. Let's enjoy our meal.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Okay, then I'll tell you something funny. You know who I mean by Dr. Raszeja.

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: The surgeon?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: The surgeon. Well, for some reason, don't ask me why, the Germans allowed him into the ghetto to perform an operation...

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: On a Jew? They allowed a Pole to come in to operate on a Jew?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: He got a pass, that's all I know. Anyway, he puts the patient to sleep and starts the operation. He'd just made the first incision when the SS burst in, shoot the patient lying on the table, and then shoot Dr. Raszeja and everybody else who was there. Isn't that a laugh? The patient didn't feel a thing, he was anaesthetised -

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Henryk, I said nothing bad.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: What's the matter with you all? Have you lost your sense of humour?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: It's not funny.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Well, you know what's funny? You're funny with that ridiculous tie.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What are you talking about, my tie? What's my tie got to do with anything? I need the tie for my work.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Boys, boys...

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Your work, yes, playing the piano for all the parasites in the ghetto, they don't give a damn about people's sufferings, they don't even notice what's going on around them!

Speaker: father
Dialogue: I blame the Americans.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: For what? For my tie?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: American Jews, and there's lots of them, what have they done for us? What do they think they're doing? People here are dying, haven't got a bite to eat. The Jewish bankers over there should be persuading America to declare war on Germany!

Speaker: nco
Dialogue: Stand up!

Speaker: nco
Dialogue: Stand up!

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: Be quiet, Mama, for God's sake, be quiet!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What's happened?

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: Oh my God, it's terrible, you've got to do something, oh my God!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Calm down, what, what is it?

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: They're hunting people on the streets. They've picked up Henryk.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I'm afraid not.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What's happening?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Yitzchak!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Yitzchak!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Here, please! Wladek Szpilman!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Henryk's in there.

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: I haven't seen him.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Believe me, they've picked him up.

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: Tough luck.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Can you help?

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: Oh, you need me now, yes, now you need me!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Can you help us?

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: It costs.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I've no money.

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: Then there's nothing I can do. He should've joined us when I gave him the chance..

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Yitzchak, they told me you had influence.

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: Who told you?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: People I know. They said you're an important man.

Speaker: poor woman
Dialogue: A snatcher! Help me, a snatcher!

Speaker: rubinstein's voice
Dialogue: Boys, keep your peckers up! And girls, keep your legs crossed!

Speaker: rubinstein
Dialogue: Don't let 'em get you down -

Speaker: rubinstein
Dialogue: Bandits! Crooks!  Thieves!

Speaker: rubinstein
Dialogue: If that means good day, I'm your man, you gangsters, robbers, pirates!

Speaker: rubinstein
Dialogue: Ich bin meshuge, you bandit!

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: You go to Heller, did I ask you to talk to him?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: You're out, aren't you?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Did you beg, did you grovel to that piece of shit, that cockroach?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I didn't grovel, I asked him to help.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: What did you pay him?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Pay him? With what? With what could I pay him? Every zloty I earn we spend on food!

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: I can look after myself!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: They were taking you away.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: It's nothing to do with you. It's me they wanted, not you. Why do you interfere in other people's business?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: You're mad, that's your trouble, you're mad.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: That's also my business.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What's the matter? Are you sick?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Hungry.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What's that mean, no employment certificate?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: You have to have an employment certificate to work for one of the German firms in the ghetto, otherwise...

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Otherwise what?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: You'll be deported.

Speaker: benek
Dialogue: So the rumours were true...

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: They're going to resettle us. Send us to labour camps. In the east. And they're closing the small ghetto.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: Wladek!

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: I thought you'd be off on tour, playing London, Paris, New York?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Not this week.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: I have to say you look terrible. What's the trouble?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: You've heard the rumours they're going to resettle us in the East?

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: Rumours, rumours, you take it all too much to heart, Wladek.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I've been trying to get a certificate of employment for my father. I've managed to get certificates for me and the rest of the family but I need one more for my father. I've been trying all the firms, the shops...

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: Why didn't you come to me?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I didn't know you were in the certificate business.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: I'm not, but Majorek is.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Can you help? I've no money...

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: Please, don't insult us.  Can you do something for him?

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: Be at the Schultz Workshop, tomorrow, four o'clock.

Speaker: jehuda
Dialogue: You see what a wonderful piece of luck you've had today? That's die historical imperative in action and that's why I always say, look on...

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: ...the bright side, yes, I know.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: schultz
Dialogue: My pleasure. It won't help you anyway.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: At least we've got work in the ghetto. At least we're still together.

Speaker: nco
Dialogue: Out! Assemble in the yard!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: We're employed here, we've got certificates -

Speaker: nco
Dialogue: The rest of you get dressed then report back here. Bring your belongings. Fifteen kilos only.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I did my best, I thought the certificates would save us all.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Stop it, Wladek.

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: Let's just hope that Henryk and Halina will be better off -

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: Where will we be going?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Let's sit over there.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: I can hear you.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Dr. Ehrlich, not so loud!

Speaker: grun
Dialogue: Why you so sure they're sending us to our death?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Dr. Ehrlich, what do you want me to do? You want me to fight?

Speaker: grun
Dialogue: To fight you need organisation, plans, guns!

Speaker: father
Dialogue: He's right. What d'you think I can do? Fight them with my violin bow?

Speaker: grun
Dialogue: The Germans would never squander a huge labour force like this. They're sending us to a labour camp.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Henryk!

Speaker: regina
Dialogue: Oh my God!

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Halina! Henryk!

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: We heard you were here...we...didn't want...we...we wanted to be with you.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Stupid, stupid!

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: She's getting on my nerves. What did she do, for God's sake?

Speaker: grun
Dialogue: She smothered her baby.

Speaker: grun
Dialogue: They'd prepared a hiding place and so, of course, they went there. But the baby cried just as the police came. She smothered the cries with her hands. The baby died. A policeman heard the death rattle. He found where they were hiding.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What are you reading?

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: 'If you prick us, do we not bleed? If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?'

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Very appropriate.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Yes, that's why I brought it.

Speaker: henryk
Dialogue: Idiot. What's he think he's going to do with the money?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: How much for a caramel?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: What? For one caramel? What d'you think you're going to do with the money?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Have we got twenty between us?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Halina?

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Funny time to say this.

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: wish I knew you better.

Speaker: halina
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: a voice
Dialogue: Szpilman! Szpilman!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Papa!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Papa! Mama! Halina!

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: What do you think you're doing, Szpilman? I've saved your life! Now, go on, save yourself!

Speaker: heller
Dialogue: Don't run!

Speaker: jewish policeman
Dialogue: Well, off they go for meltdown!

Speaker: benek
Dialogue: Why are you here, Mr. Wladek?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: It's like this... I...we...all of them.

Speaker: benek
Dialogue: Perhaps they're lucky. The quicker the better.  I've bribed a policeman. He'll come when it's over.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: My God. I haven't been outside for - it must be two years.

Speaker: fellow worker
Dialogue: Don't get over-excited.

Speaker: dealers
Dialogue: Gold, buy gold! Dollars! Roubles!

Speaker: benek
Dialogue: Someone you know?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: benek
Dialogue: A beauty. Who is she?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: A singer. Her husband's an actor. I knew them well. Good people. I'd like to talk to her.

Speaker: benek
Dialogue: Don't forget, Mr. Wladek, they hang them for helping Jews.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: How long have you been here?

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: Since last night. I was pleased to see you.

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: They're going to start the final resettlement now. We know what it means. We sent someone out. Zygmunt. A good man. His orders were to follow the trains out of Warsaw. He got to Sokolow. A local railwayman told him the tracks are divided, one branch leading to Treblinka. He said every day freight trains carrying people from Warsaw forked to Treblinka and returned empty. No transports of food are ever seen on that line. And civilians are forbidden to approach the Treblinka station. They're exterminating us. Won't take them long. We're sixty thousand left. Out of half a million. Mostly young people. And this time we're going to fight. We're in good shape. We're organised. We're prepared.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: If you need help...

Speaker: bartczak
Dialogue: Hope you played the piano better than you carry bricks.

Speaker: polish workman
Dialogue: He won't last long if he goes on like this.

Speaker: bartczak
Dialogue: I'll see if I can get him something better.

Speaker: worker
Dialogue: Trouble.

Speaker: ss captain
Dialogue: I have important and good news for you. There are rumours circulating that resettlement measures are again going to be taken.

Speaker: ss captain
Dialogue: I want to assure you personally that no such measures will be taken now or in the future. Posters will be going up also to this effect. As proof of our good will, we want you to select a delegate, who will be permitted to go into town once a day to buy, on each worker's behalf, five kilos of potatoes and one loaf of bread, which you will be allowed to take back into the ghetto. Now, why would we do that j if we meant to resettle you?

Speaker: ss captain
Dialogue: You can do good business on what you don't eat. Isn't that what you Jews are best at? Making 'geld'?

Speaker: ss captain
Dialogue: Carry on.

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: The smaller one. At the bottom.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Majorek!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Have a favour to ask. I want to get out of here.

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: It's easy to get out, it's how you survive on the other side that's hard.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I know. But last summer, I worked for a day in Zelazna Brama Square. I saw someone I knew. A singer. Her husband's an actor. They're old friends.  I've written their names down. And their address. If they're still there. Janina Godlewska and Andrzej Bogucki. Good people. Majorek, you go into the town every day. Would you try and make contact? Ask them if they'd help me get out of here?

Speaker: ss lieutenant
Dialogue: Any fucking plaster?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: We're allowed to take food into the ghetto. Five kilos of potatoes and a...

Speaker: ss lieutenant
Dialogue: Open it.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: It's only potatoes and bread.

Speaker: ss lieutenant
Dialogue: Fuck that, you're lying, I can smell it. Open it.

Speaker: ss lieutenant
Dialogue: You're all the same. Give a Jew a little finger, he takes the whole hand.

Speaker: ss lieutenant
Dialogue: You lie to me again and I'll shoot you personally.

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: I tried your friends. They're not at that address any more.  But.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: You made contact?

Speaker: majorek
Dialogue: Be ready to leave in two days' time. Same place as last night.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Oh, shit!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: No. Why?

Speaker: all workers
Dialogue: Hey, ranks unite And follow the White Eagle! Stand up and fight Our mortal enemy. Riflemen, hey! Let's give them fire and brimstone. We'll blow away The yoke of slavery. Punish and rout The rapists of our nation. We'll smash the knout To save our dignity. Soon we'll be proud Of our liberation -

Speaker: german voices
Dialogue: Get on with it and fall in! Fall in!

Speaker: bogucki
Dialogue: We haven't much time.

Speaker: bogucki
Dialogue: You must hurry.

Speaker: bogucki
Dialogue: We're going to have to keep moving you. The Germans are hunting down indiscriminately now. Jews, non- Jews, anybody, everybody.  See if these fit. And, Wladek, you'd better shave. Use my razor. In the cabinet.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Thank you, I don't.

Speaker: bogucki
Dialogue: You'll be looked after by Mr Gebczynski. He's on the other side of town. You'll stay there tonight. Then we'll find you somewhere else.

Speaker: janina
Dialogue: I'll bring you food.

Speaker: bogucki
Dialogue: Let's go.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: I'll show you where you're going to sleep.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: It's not going to be very comfortable.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I'll be fine.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: You'll have to stay here until tomorrow afternoon.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: We've got a flat for you. Near the ghetto wall. But it's safe.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: Go as near to the front as possible, to the German section.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: Must feel better this side of the wall.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Yes, but sometimes I'm still not sure which side of the wall I'm on.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: I'll come again. And Janina Bogucki will visit twice a week. Bring more food. See how you are.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: Yes, now, this is very important. In case of emergency, I mean emergency, go to this address.

Speaker: kitten's voice
Dialogue: Puppydog, what d'you mean, you forgot?

Speaker: puppydog's voice
Dialogue: What d'you think I mean, Kitten? I forgot, that's what I mean.

Speaker: kitten's voice
Dialogue: You know what? You treat me like dirt!

Speaker: puppydog's voice
Dialogue: I treat you like dirt because you are dirt.

Speaker: kitten's voice
Dialogue: Pig!

Speaker: puppydog's voice
Dialogue: Cow!

Speaker: kitten's voice
Dialogue: Pig!

Speaker: puppydog's voice
Dialogue: Bitch!

Speaker: kitten's voice
Dialogue: Dirty pig!

Speaker: puppydog's voice
Dialogue: You're a dirty pig!

Speaker: kitten's voice
Dialogue: Takes one to know one! Pig!

Speaker: puppydog's voice
Dialogue: You play like an angel, Kitten.

Speaker: kitten's voice
Dialogue: If I play like an angel, why don't you listen?

Speaker: puppydog's voice
Dialogue: I was listening, Kitten.

Speaker: kitten's voice
Dialogue: Liar, you fell asleep. Pig!

Speaker: puppydog's voice
Dialogue: Kitten, let me in.

Speaker: janina
Dialogue: wanted to come earlier but...

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: janina
Dialogue: No one thought they'd hold out so long.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: should never have come out. I should've stayed there, fought with them.

Speaker: janina
Dialogue: Wladek, stop that. It's over now. Just be proud it happened. My God, did they put up a fight.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Yes, so did the Germans.

Speaker: janina
Dialogue: They're in shock. They didn't expect it. Nobody expected it. Jews fighting back? Who'd have thought?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Yes, but what good did it do?

Speaker: janina
Dialogue: What good? Wladek, I'm surprised at you. They died with  dignity, that's what good it did. And you know something else?  Now the Poles will rise. We're ready. We'll fight, too. You'll see.

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: Get your things together, you have to leave!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What's happened?

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: I'm on the run!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What's happened?

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: The Gestapo found our weapons. They've arrested Janina and Andrzej. They're bound to find out about this place, too - you must get away at once.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Where do you want me to go?  Look at me. No, no, I'm not leaving. Can't I take my chances here?

Speaker: gebczynski
Dialogue: That's your decision.  But when they storm the flat, throw yourself out of die window - don't let them get you alive. I have poison on me, they won't get me alive either!

Speaker: kitty's voice
Dialogue: Open this door at once, or we'll call the police!

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Are you from the flat in there? You're not registered.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: It belongs to a friend of mine. I came to visit but I must have just missed him.

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: Have you got your identity card? Let me see your identity card!

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: I want to see your identity card!

Speaker: kitty
Dialogue: He's a Jew! He's a Jew! Stop the Jew! Don't let him out!

Speaker: woman's voice
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Mr Gebczynski sent me.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Wladyslaw Szpilman.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Dorota.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Come in! come in!

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Sit.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I'm sorry - I was given this address. I'm looking for a Mr--  -- a Mr Dzikiewicz.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Michal Dzikiewicz. He's my husband.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I need help.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: He'll be back before curfew.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I've been in hiding. I need somewhere to stay.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: He'll be here soon.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: How long have you been married?

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Just over a year.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: And how's Yurek?

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Dead.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: When's your baby due?

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Christmas.  This is not a good time to have children. But then...

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: This is my husband. Wladyslaw Szpilman. Marek Gebczynski sent him.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: Oh, yes. I remember.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Mr Gebczynski said to contact you only in an emergency, but...

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: Don't worry now. We can't move you tonight.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: You'll sleep on the sofa.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Excuse me, could I have a piece of bread?

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: Yes, of course, we'll eat.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: You're in a very German area. The building opposite is a hospital, taking in wounded from the Russian front. Next door is the Schutzpolizei. It's the safest place to be. Right in the centre of the lion's den.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: I'll be locking you in. No one knows you're here. So keep as quiet as possible.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: All well?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: This is Antek Szalas.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: He's going to look after you. I've given him a second key. He'll bring you food. See that you're all right. He's with the underground, a good man.

Speaker: szalas
Dialogue: You don't remember me, Mr. Szpilman?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: No, I don't think so?

Speaker: szalas
Dialogue: Warsaw Radio. I was a technician. I saw you almost every day.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Sorry, I don't remember.

Speaker: szalas
Dialogue: Doesn't matter. You've nothing to worry about. I'll visit often.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: And you'll be pleased to hear the Allies are bombing Germany night after night - Cologne, Hamburg, Berlin.

Speaker: szalas
Dialogue: And the Russians are really giving them hell. It's the beginning of the end.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: Let's hope so. I don't know when I'll see you again?

Speaker: szalas
Dialogue: Still alive then, are you? Here. Sausage. Bread.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: How long is this meant to last?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: think I've got jaundice.

Speaker: szalas
Dialogue: You don't want to worry about that. My grandfather was jilted by his girl friend when he got jaundice.  In my opinion, jaundice is not very serious. Drink up.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Why didn't you come sooner? It's been over two weeks.

Speaker: szalas
Dialogue: Problems. Money. I've got to raise money to buy the food. I need things to sell, it' s not easy.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Sell this. Food's more important than time.

Speaker: szalas
Dialogue: Oh, yes. I meant to tell you. The Allies have landed in France. The Russians'll be here soon. They'll beat the shit out of the Germans. Any day now.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Wladek? Wladek!  I knew it, I knew this would happen!

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: I'm going to get a doctor.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: You can't, it's too dangerous.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: I'll get Dr Luczak, we can trust him.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: Dorota, don't be ridiculous, he's a pediatrician.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: He's still a doctor.

Speaker: michal
Dialogue: No, you stay, I'll go.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: We came to say goodbye. We're going to stay with my mother in Otwock.The baby's already there. It's safer. There's talk that the uprising will begin any day now.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: That man Szalas should be shot. He's been collecting money on your behalf all over Warsaw. Apparently, people gave generously. So he collected a tidy sum. He told us he was visiting you daily.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Oh God!

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Acute inflammation of the gall bladder. Liver the size of a football. But he'll live. I'll try to get hold of some levulose, but it's not easy.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Can you visit him again?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Who knows?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Doctor, thank you.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Don't speak. Rest.

Speaker: dorota
Dialogue: Michal brought food. I'll prepare something now for you, then we must go.

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: Where? Where? Just get out! Everywhere! Get out into the street!

Speaker: german voice
Dialogue: Fourth floor, Fischke!

Speaker: german voice
Dialogue: At the double, Fischke!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I was... I was trying to open this tin.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I am... I was a pianist.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: In the attic.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What's all that gunfire?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What's happening?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Are the Russians here?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I don't know how to thank you.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: What about you?

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I'll play the piano again. On Polish radio.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Szpilman.

Speaker: loudspeaker voice
Dialogue: ...German army! Polish soil liberated!  Official!

Speaker: the woman
Dialogue: German! German!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Stop, for God's sake, I beg you, I'm Polish!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Don't shoot! I'm Polish!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: Don't shoot! I'm Polish! Please, please! I'm Polish!

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: I'm cold.

Speaker: lednicki
Dialogue: Murderers! Assassins!  Look at you now! You took everything I had! Me, a musician!  You took my violin! You took my soul!

Speaker: lednicki
Dialogue: Yes, of course, I know Szpilman.

Speaker: russian guard
Dialogue: Hey! No talking to the prisoners. Get away from there!

Speaker: lednicki
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: lednicki
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: lednicki
Dialogue: It was here, I'm certain of it.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: It's not here now.

Speaker: lednicki
Dialogue: I shouted abuse at them, I'm not proud of it, but that's what I did, and, I'm certain, I stood where you are now. There was barbed wire, and this German came up to me.

Speaker: szpilman
Dialogue: You didn't catch his name.

Speaker: lednicki
Dialogue: No. I'll ask at the factory. They may know something.
